French zoologist and an authority on deviation from normal structure. He coined
the term ethology.

He was born in Paris, the son of Ãtienne Geoffroy Saint-Hilaire. In his earlier
years he showed an aptitude for mathematics, but eventually he devoted himself
to the study of natural history and of medicine, and in 1824 he was appointed

In 1829 he delivered for his father the second part of a course of lectures on
ornithology, and during the three following years he taught zoology at the
AthÃ©nÃ©e, and teratology at the Ãcole pratique. He was elected a member of the
French Academy of Sciences in 1833, was in 1837 appointed to act as deputy for
his father at the faculty of sciences in Paris, and in the following year was
sent to Bordeaux to organize a similar faculty there. He became successively
inspector of the academy of Paris (1840), professor of the museum on the

member of the royal council for public instruction (1845), and on the death of
Henri Marie Ducrotay de Blainville, professor of zoology at the faculty of
sciences (1850). In 1854 he founded the Acclimatization Society of Paris, of
which he was president.
